description: From Middle English charite, from Old French charité, cherte, chariteit, cariteit, from Latin cāritās.

entries.meaning: (countable) An organization, the objective of which is to carry out a charitable purpose.
(countable) The goods or money given to those in need.
(uncountable) Benevolence to others less fortunate than ourselves; the providing of goods or money to those in need.
In general, an attitude of kindness and understanding towards others, now especially suggesting generosity.
examples: Judge thyself with the judgment of sincerity, and thou witl judge others with the judgment of charity.

entries.meaning: (archaic, Christianity) Christian love; representing God's love of man, man's love of God, or man's love of his fellow-men.
